lsts2 2.0
  • Reference

Smooth Periodogram by Blocks

Source: R/block_smooth_periodogram.R
block_smooth_periodogram.Rd

Plots the contour plot of the smoothing periodogram of a time series, by blocks or windows.

block_smooth_periodogram(
  y,
  x = NULL,
  w = NULL,
  s = NULL,
  p = 0.25,
  spar_freq = 0,
  spar_time = 0
)

Arguments

y

(type: numeric) data vector
x

(type: numeric) optional vector, if x = NULL then the function uses \((1,\ldots,n)\) where n is the length of y. More details in y argument from persp function.
w

(type: numeric) value corresponding to the length of the window to compute periodogram. If w=NULL then the function will use \(w = \text{trunc}(n^{0.8})\), see Dahlhaus and Giraitis (1998) where \(n\) is the length of the y vector.
s

(type: numeric) value corresponding to the lag with which will be taking the blocks or windows to calculate the periodogram.
p

(type: numeric) value used if it is desired that s is proportional to w. By default p=0.25, if s and w are not entered.
spar_freq

(type: numeric) smoothing parameter, typically (but not necessarily) in \((0,1]\).
spar_time

(type: numeric) smoothing parameter, typically (but not necessarily) in \((0,1]\).

Value

A ggplot object

Details

The number of windows of the function is \(m = \text{trunc}((n-w)/s+1)\), where trunc truncates de entered value and n is the length of the vector y. All windows are of the same length w, if this value isn't entered by user then is computed as \(w=\text{trunc}(n^{0.8})\) (Dahlhaus).

lsts2_spb computes the periodogram in each of the M windows and then smoothes it two times with smooth.spline function; the first time using spar_freq parameter and the second time with spar_time. These windows overlap between them.

References

For more information on theoretical foundations and estimation methods see

Dahlhaus R, others (1997). “Fitting time series models to nonstationary processes.” The annals of Statistics, 25(1), 1--37.

Dahlhaus R, Giraitis L (1998). “On the optimal segment length for parameter estimates for locally stationary time series.” Journal of Time Series Analysis, 19(6), 629--655.

See also

arima.sim

Examples

block_smooth_periodogram(malleco)

Contents
